sp.p: My husband here! I'll stop a little—

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: 'Twill not belong e're we shall acquaint you with what We require in order to your obedience.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: We are your subjects already Ladies—but to tell you truth—Here is a Gentleman that is a small dissenter, having Had some diff'rence lately with his wife, about Supremacy.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: A small contest Ladies, as much as came to a blow with the Smart of my hand; or so.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And somewhat betwixt your feet, was't not?

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: I thank your remembrance; but I am so good natur'd that I chastise her first, and forgive her afterwards.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Do you so Sir?
sp.stage: Fopp. offers to go out. Frank. holds him.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Nay, make it good now Sir.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: And has brag'd I should be no Mistriss Magistrate Of the Common-wealth, has he not?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I suppose he will not deny it.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: Excuse me Sir, as I am a man in favour with the Stars I am in haste?—

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: I'll stay it a little—And have t'other Slipper of the Moons to sind; have you so Sir?

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: As sure as she dropt this in yonder Grove Wife!

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.p: In the mean time, I could find in my heart to make Use of it about your pate.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: Do not profane it so I beseech thee, tho' to tell thee the Truth, I cannot chuse but be in love with her horns.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Perhaps I may bestow a pair on you in time—and then For your belying of me, and our Sexes Authority.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: Thou know'st I love to talk for my Credit, or so.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: And disparage my superiority, do you?

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: By both my ears, which are at thy service, I Scorn it Wife.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Would I could come at thy tongue as well.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: No more good Madam.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Am I fit to govern now Sirr ah?

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: By this hand of thine, which I kiss thus, and honour as the Scepter of my obedience, Thou art, as thou know'st I was Never against it betwixt our selves.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You must interpose Ladies, or here will be a battery at least.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: La. Enough, enough, Madam.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: And remember you come not near my bed till I command you.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: Not I, by my manhood, of which thou hast had so often The better.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Perhaps I'll next send you to travail, and be sure if I Do, you return a fine Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: I'll do my utmost endeavour, Wife.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: It may be, come back a verier fool than he went: I have known it so in some.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: In the mean time expect my further orders—and take a care How you tell any more tales of the Moon.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Away, away Tom!—But for this accident we should Not have been rid of him so pleasantly.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: But I'll be in love with the Moon, in spight of her Teeth, if I please.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Ladies! I beg your excuse for this passion of mine, tho' 'tis m • Fortune to have a Husband of a more weak and impotent Sence, than some others in the World.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: We conceive you, Madam!—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: A few more examples of this kind were motives enough For us to use our Legislative power against marriage; it Makes people fall so foul upon one another.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: That would live kindly otherwise. And consequently such a Mischeivous Conjunction,

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: For what concernes my interest in a husband, might I Not be thought partial, I should give my vote with the First.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And how would you provide for love, Ladies, then. As Many years as I tell, I should be loth to live without it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: God a mercy for thy Quaere i'faith old boy.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Methinks he should not be one and twenty by his humour.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Bating his age, I have not known any thing more Taking.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: But for your Quaere, 'tis as easily resolv'd as askt, There being many other ways to provide for the Toy you Talk of.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: And may please flesh and blood as well I judge.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Besides we women are not so little acquainted With those soft Intrigues, as to want due Caution, Without being beholding to a Matrimonial vow, which Men make no more conscience to break, than to gather Black-berries, or kindling of fire abroad, when their Own will not burn at home.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Gravely resolv'd! Here comes
Our President, and other of our Magistracy.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: I perceive by your familiarities the men have comply'd.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: We dare assure it you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: In order to which, you'l soon have the acknowledgments Of our late Magistrates.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: 'Tis well they have sav'd us the labour of obtaining our Rights otherwise.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: What a Race of Amazons would these make?

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: Please you, to our affairs now.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: But first Ladies I have a favour to entreat.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: That we joyn in a Dance, and as you have the Power Oblige us with a little of your mirth.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: 'Tis something unseasonable.—But what say you Ladies?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: I am not against it.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Nor any of us.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: Begin then, and take your Lady, Sir.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: By your favour Madam.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And I'll be here!—

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And let the Tune be, A merry world my Masters.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You should have said Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: I meant as much.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: For your Mirths sake you shall lead the Dance, Sir.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: I acknowledg it a favour Madam.
Now Ladies you have not found Me old.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: You have youth in abundance still,

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Wer't not for a blush I would say something a little More kind.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ladies we are yours.
sp.stage: Enter a man with Stools and Table.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And if you have such another merry subject as
My self under your republick blame me for't!

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: Since you allow me the honour of
Being your president, my place is here.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: With all acknowledgment.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: And what shall be our future Government?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Say, we elect a Monarchess amongst our selves.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: I dissent by your favour Madam, because not so natural In our Sex to endure a superior.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Right Madam, and the very reason, that induces not a few of us To be out of love with Matrimony, which doth rather establish The Tyranny of men, than the Law of nature.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: Well said, smart one.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And has made her Husband sensibe accordingly.—

sp.speaker: Crip.
sp.p: Is there not a government to be thought on, that admits neither Equal nor Superior, because it is most natural for Us Women to endure neither.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: That's Impossible.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: I find my inclinations to Anarchy.

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p: And why, Madam?

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: Because most suitable to change.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: A reason womanish enough.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: But that's no Government—My vote is rather For a Common-wealth, not only as it has been here before In Men, but as it brings us to a nearer equality.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: But how shall we agree on wit, servants, and especially Beauty, since the most capital Emulation amongst women Is like that of the Goddesses, who shall be thought fairest.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: That we must take upon our servants word, or trust our Glasses for—but what say you to a Common-wealth?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: I'll follow my President. Eug. And I. Omn. And all.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: Then from this hour begins our fair Republick.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Some of the City desire admittance.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: They have it. Your business Citizens?

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.p: 'Tis in the name of this City and Countrey, to present your Fair, and Gratious Republick, with all these representations Of power that belong'd to us as men.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: A discreet Citizen!
sp.stage: [They deliver a Mace, Sword and Charter.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: And speaks home to our purpose,

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: But for your Charter, wee'l Grace your City so far as to Grant a new one to your Wives.

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.p: Nay Ladies entitle not our wives supream, tho' you Command us.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.p: Let us continue our Prerogatives over them we beseech you.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: How, how, how, the command of your Wives?

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: A very Treason, President, that would except their Wives the most trusty and sure confidents of our Government.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Away, Away!

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: You brow-Antler-men.

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p: Things of more forehead than brain.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Speak against our Prerogative, you wagtails, to Little purpose!

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: Nay Ladies, you must be more moderate.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: You must excuse us in this case.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: In which consists so essentially our supremacy.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Cit. Good Ladies hear your President.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: For my share I'de be content with a reasonable accommodation.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: But were you a wife!

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I know not how my mind might alter then.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: What we may determine in this case, ought to be With due respect and caution—and for your Wives, they May continue yours.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.p: We thank your Grace.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.p: A Comfortable Expression!

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: We do not mean absolutely, so long as you please, But whilst they please, and you deserve their respects.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: And are obedient Husbands, mark that Citizens.—

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Lad. There we comply.

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.p: Let me have power on mine, until she's old, I'll Desire her no longer, as I am a true Citizen of Eutopia.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.p: And so of mine, whilst she is good condition'd, or honest, I ask no more.

sp.speaker: 3. Cit.
sp.p: I was marry'd but yesterday, and if you do not mitigate This decree, 'tis odds but she may long for change already, And part with me before I have had so much as the better Of her Virginity.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: That were severe indeed.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Better an inconvenience, than a general mischief.

sp.speaker: 4. Cit.
sp.p: My spouse is old, and to save her a labour, I am Content to depart from her first, if your Republick Shall think fit to allow it.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: I suppose you would.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: But that were against charity.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: And the humanity we allow.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Right, Madam: When the flower is gone, there is no reason To cast away the root.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: I rather conceive we ought to judg them old, when we Find occasion, and not they presume to censure us for being so.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: Betwixt both Sexes some mean were necessary, For which you shall be referr'd to our Courts, where every Particular Case shall have due respect, and justice.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: But for Alimony, in case of separation?

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p: I suppose when that's in question the men must sue Us.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: As you are Superior they must, but not be vex'd With delays by way of retaliation, as some of our Sex may pretend to have been: all cases shall have a Just and soon dispatch—you agree Ladies?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: All with our President.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: So much is for your comfort, Citizens.

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.p: Since we must be overwiv'd, and top'd every way, We cannot but acknowledg it.

sp.speaker: Omn. Cit.
sp.p: And so we humbly take our leaves.—

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: Having thus resolv'd of our government, 'twill be Requisite to consider how we shall maintain it. In relation to Peace and War.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: A necessary consideration: and no less the concern Of our ambitions and honour.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And must we likewise in imitation of the warlike Amazons lead our Sex to battel?

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: If cause require, we must.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: I hope there's none of us but dare.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: Or we'll be more masculine than ever were those martial Females, and lead the men, who shall serve as souldiers Under us commanders.

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p: I long to be a Captain.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: I suppose I have shew'd you the way how to have the Better of men at home, in beginning with my Husband; Wherefore I expect no inconsiderable command otherwise.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: But I hope, you'l not be oblig'd to fight; I should Be sorry to be your leader on such an account.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And I to be a follower, though I should as unwillingly Turn tail as any she amongst us.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: Within wee'l more at large debate of this and other Our concerns.

lg.l: And by our Rule let us instruct men so,
That they may yield our vertues greatest too.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Not acknowledg'd by your Father yet?

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Nor ever like, if heaven be not more my friend than he.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Who does teach repentance, he ne're means to practise: The common road of all Hypocrisy.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: I blush for his sake.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And so do I; To see him declaim against vice, yet Privately affect it, as if there were no way to reform Prodigality, without being in love with Covetousness

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Thence comes my injury and grief, for tho' his Nature be Severe, and not so good as I would wish my Father: his Covetousness does far exceed it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: A vice as universal as love, Featlin—But this is such A hideous Crime, I know not what to call it in him.

sp.speaker: Feat.
sp.p: My Mother dying in my Infant years, as I was her only Most unfortunate Son, He as an Example of covetousness And Cruelty in Fathers, dispos'd of me for a small summe (tho' Very young) to be brought up; and since permits me not into His sight.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And for no cause.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Not as I ever knew, or can judge any, except he has Inclination to marry, and have other issue, or else give his Estate for his future Glory to erect an Hospital, or such Like act to preserve his Memory.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: He is not so charitable, and use thee thus! A parish does not 'Prentice out a Beggars child a cheaper way, or a Gentleman his by-blow, lest he should blush in the Future to owne his issue—Dost thou not know him now?

sp.speaker: Feat.
sp.p: I did not until lately shew'd him, nor will he know me If he might, by any application I can gather.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: What kindness has providence vouchsaf'd thee For thy subsistance hitherto?

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Some Jewels, which my Mother dying committed to a hand Of trust, have been the means I do appear so like my Self; My manners I have travel'd to improve; visited Camps, and Courts abroad, as the most generous Schools Of youth—But what will be my future destiny?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Trouble not thy self with Fate, as 'tis hidden from us, So let it take care of it self and us too, for Frankman. Be merry, and think my Sword, purse, and best wit shall Be at thy service.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Your expressions are too great and many apply'd to Me so much a stranger to you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I do believe it just; that's obligation to a Gentleman. Besides the Government is now the womens.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: I understand it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Thou hast a smooth face, and the Common-wealth has Many soft, and fair members to be laid hold on.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Some Ladies I have visited, and perhaps have my Concerns of love besides; so farre I'll be Ingenious with you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And much joy may it do thy heart! For my part, I had as leave see a Castril sport With the Wine, as a man generous and youthful, That has nothing to do with Venus.—
Sir Adam Meredith!—
Here's a Gentleman that will deserve your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And is he Airy, Jocund, and gay, as his age declares him?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Doubt it not Sir, tho' at present he suffers by some concern, You shall know more at leisure.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Why then, I embrace thee brother youth as a Socio of My Mirth; thy father cannot wish thee better.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Would he did but as well—A humour I have not Observ'd at his years.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: What are years to me? Tho' time has snow'd on my head, I have a Summer in my heart, and am firm at the Center still, Ladd.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: May it continue Sir!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: There's little doubt of that; 'thas been long his humour, & Rather improves of late.
sp.stage: Enter Peacock looking on himself and pruning of his Feathers.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: O! here's Peacock come again.—

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: One of the newest humours extant amongst us.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: I believe it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: If you knew all you'd say more—He's in love with Himself.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p:
That's no great novelty, since the greatest part of mankind
Have kindness enough for themselves.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But he comes nearer Narcissus.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Or rather exceeds him.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And as you see, admires his looks, his proportions, and when He has done, makes love to himself all over.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: And to his Feathers too, methinks.—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I'll tell you what he has endeavour'd besides; make good What I say, Peacock!

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: as far as these Feathers can fly I am at your service Mr. Frankman.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Thou Bird of Manhood, I thank thee—And thou hast Been with the Artist I told thee off—

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: I have Sir.—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And has he perform'd?

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: To my utmost desire Sir; and like a most skilful Chymist Has extracted the same man as I am—out of me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Look you there Gentlemen, he has been made twice without Being well begotten once—I told you there was more Miracle behind.—

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: By which means I am now in love with my self, twice Over, (that is to say) I am doubly the same.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: As two individual things may be in one, that's his Meaning!—

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: This is novelty indeed.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Our Countrey is famous for nothing so much, and I hope I am Some part on't my self, I should be angry with my age otherwise—and how was this effected?

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: Why Sir, by only bidding me blow pretty hard into a Cruciter, I think he calls it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: A Crucible—thou Coxcomb!—

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And what next?

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: Why Sir, I infus'd so much of my self into it, that meeting With fire and Air, artificially working together, perfected At last such another gross substance as I am.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: This is a perfect Chymist I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: A Quack that I advis'd him to, for a little diversion, And punishment of his folly together.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p:
And more for your comforts Gentlemen, he'll make you all as Many times over, if you please. Alas! he can make men As fast as they do Puppits; but that he is not willing
To encrease the price of Bread-Corn, he has told me his Mind so far.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And what was his price? I suppose he us'd you well.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: I assure you Sir, This second production of my self stands Me but in twenty nobles betwixt friends.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I knew hee'd use you kindly.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: By this good light, a man cannot get a child by the By, so cheap, let him use the best husbandry he Can.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And when shall we see this other self of yours?

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: Why Sir, so satisfie your curiosity, I will appear In my double person immediately.—

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: By any means Sir, methinks I long like a Maid in love, till I behold this prodigy.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: Why Sir, I was but hard by a putting on another Habit, the Artist desiring that he or I in him Might continue a space with him while I was Talking with you here.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And be sure bring this great Master of Art with you. I would not lose the curiosity of seeing him.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: I shall Sir, on your secrecy.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Nay; 'prethee dispatch.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: I shall Gentlemen, and if any of you have a mind to Be made once more as I am, you may have it done.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: A most new and excellent example Of self-love.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: A sign the world and time renews again—has not his Character been upon the Stage yet?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I believe not; Tho' the age has been so ransack'd for humour, That men are in some fear to converse freely, lest they be Heard again in the next new Play.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: That's some good fortune for him I'll assure you. But see—here comes the man-maker.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Your name Sir?

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: I am called Orlando Curioso.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: A very Emphatical name.

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: 'T was bestow'd on me in Spain; I assure you Sir, as no Small honour to my Art.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
Nay, 'prethee let his Denomination alone, I'd as soon study
Arabick or learn his Art (that signifies little more than Hard Words) as hear it twice.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: O Sir, I remember you now, and have read your cures and works Set up like Trophies on posts and pillars of our City; Where amongst other things you undertook to reduce Age to Youth, and turn hair silver'd over like mine By time, to a brown-colour, and soft as Gostimores—Is't not so?

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: And am ready to undertake it if you'l prove my Experiments.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: You shall excuse me Sir, I am young enough without it, I thank this heart of mine.

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: I do such like feats, with some negligence Of my Art, and deeper Science, as the restoring of men And women to their first vigor, producing of hair As long as Perriwiggs, tho' they have shed from the Skull by siccation, and baldness, or other defects above Or below. If I look in a mouth, I know what tooth Will decay, and the minute when, preventing it accordingly.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And what more? I know you are but on the outside Of your Art yet.

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: If a Lady be curious & would know her fortune by her hand, I spare her the labour and tell it by her eye.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: A pleasant Symptom.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: And most possible of all the particulars he has nam'd yet.

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: Or if she have a mind to dream pleasantly, she shall do It, as well at 50, as at 21. and so to fourscore or upwards. If a man or woman wear but a ring that has a small Tincture of my Art, they shall fall in love without being Beholding to Hymen.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why, so they do already, Buzzard.

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: Besides I have my several Spirits of Sulphur, Mercury And Salt.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: The last of which will powder Beef, will it not?

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: I have printed it's use (amongst others) to that purpose. And for my Sulphur and Mercury, it does wonders As some Gallants can witness.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Cures the Itch, does it not?

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: And what is got by the worst of Itches too—then for My Spirit of Salt of the world.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: A soul of Salt we shall hear of.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And not enough for the Earth to produce.

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: Nor the Sea neither; together with my Elixar proprietatis, Et procreationis.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: That's a new word, the other I have known sold before.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: But ne'er worth my buying.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No more of hard words.

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: To conclude then, with the two last mysteries of my skill, I do all that can be desir'd by men and women.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: That they shall not decay or dye.
sp.stage: Enter Peacock and Euphorbus drest like him, hugging one another.

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: The first I can say much to, & for the latter I may undertake It in time—there is a Paracelsian Recipe for that, call'd Ens naturae, as likewise how to make men (as you'l witness I perform) tho' not effectually practis'd by any man, Besides my self to this day.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And can you make a wise man out of a fool as easily, since The World does beget fools enough, without help of your Art.

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: I do not say as easily, wherefore I do not care to effect many Artificial Examples of that kind, tho' nature (according to The learned) gives but one soul to all things in the most differing Bodies. If I am to deal with a wiseman, (as our art of Chymistry has been beholding to some so farr as To honour it by the ruine of their estates) I deal one Way with him, if with a fool another; let this worthy Gentleman be my testimony.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: A pertinent one.
And have you performed this wonderful propagation of him In so short a time?

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: I am as well prepar'd in an hour as in seven years.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: I believe so.

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: Not any wait, as is usual (with Other Artists) on the most superlative operation I Undertake to produce.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p:
I will justifie thy Art Schollar, as I am doubly a man of
Thy making. Observe here, Gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: How they kiss like Twins of two years old.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: But he thinks he kisses himself all the while, that's The jest on't—and how many men have you made in This manner before.

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: Not many Sir, or desire it, because not so gracious to Mankind, Who are willing to continue their natural way of Generation; Tho' I have had application made to me to that purpose From an Island newly inhabited in the Atlantick-Ocean, where They are necessitated (for want of people) to engender with Baboons, Drils, and Monkeys.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: You are famous abroad as well as at home then?—

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: As you see Gentlemen! Where I gain confidence and sit Instruments, my endeavours are not wanting.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I suppose so.

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: 'Tis not every Tree produces Cherries, nor every Quarry Diamonds; There must be a propensity in nature to assit Art.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And these your examples?

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: O my dear self, my dear self! How shall I love Thee enough, my dear self?

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: A pretty kind of love.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: And this Eye, this Lip, this Cheek of mine, which no longing Maid living shall rob me of.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: She were but ill sped if she did: but methinks the other Speaks not.

sp.speaker: Eupho.
sp.p: Ga, ga, ga, ga, ga, ga, &c.

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: But offers at it.

sp.speaker: Eupho.
sp.p: Ga, ga, ga, ga, ga, ga, &c.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: His name?

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: He is call'd Euphorbus, in honour of Pythagoras's own Transmigration.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And is he to be always dumb?

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: A still-born perhaps.

sp.speaker: Eupho.
sp.p: Da, da, da, da, pa, pa, pa, pa, &c.

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: He gargles words pretty towardly already, as children usually do; In time Sir, he may speak too, tho' in order of Nature, speech Comes not so soon as life.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: I care not much if I talk always for him, and if any body has Any thing to say to him, they shall be answer'd by me in him.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—one tongue serve two men.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Would it might serve two women too, the world would Not be so busy as it is.

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your excuse: my works require me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But hark you Sir, remember you do not practise to make More men; for this time I'll excuse you for Mirth's sake.

sp.speaker: Orlan.
sp.p: I understand you Sir.—
sp.stage: Enter Foppering making of legs and looking upwards.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Who have we here?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: One that will tell you he believs as much.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: But not in love with himself too? is he?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No, but what is worse, dotes on his own lying, nay Sometimes will tell his tales so long untill he be in love With them as much as if they were truths—after the manner Of some Poets, who dote on their fictions, tho' they abuse Credibility and truth together—Meridith has heard him as Well as I.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: With Admiration!
sp.stage: Fopp. goes up and down looking upwards.—

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: But why does he continue Looking upwards thus?

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: O he seems to be in love with the Moon.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Ever since his Wife beat him with a slipper he pretended to Have found of Cynthia's own wearing.—But you Shall soon inform your self—Mr. Foppering?

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: Cry your mercy Sir, I was very busy.—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And have you found the other slipper of the Moon's yet?

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: I shall have that or a greater favour from her.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Are you sure on't?

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: Tho' I have talk'd, or can talk as largely as you, or any Man, I'd have you to know I am serious now.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Very good Sir, proceed.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: And so I will, as sure as she put her hand out of yonder Cloud to me but just now.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: This is a Novelty fit to embrace with these.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: How they continue kissing still!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And shall break their Bellies if they can with it Before I part them.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: If Cynthia be but a virgin! I say no more—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You'l have her virginity then you mean.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: Marry will I Sir, there shall be no other man in the Moon Besides my self, whatsoever the Poets my masters report Of Pan, Endymion, or any shepherd of Arcadia: and I Suppose a Gentleman may be allow'd as much priviledge by Her Lady-ship in point of fiction, or otherwise.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: This is rarely pleasant.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And the more, because his humour does rather heighten Than decrease.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: Mr. Foppering.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: What joy here's towards.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: Mr. Peacock.—

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: And somewhat more yours; tho' the same yours still.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: As how Sir?

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: Why; I am doubly made.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: By whom?

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: By a Virtuoso, an Artist, a Paracelsian, who has produc'd This man out of me.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: And I'll embrace your twofold self then—nay more I'll report it for a truth, and swear it when I have done. I have wanted such a story a great while—tho' I thank Heaven I have some fictions of my own.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, - methinks I could laugh as many years More than I have liv'd, to be thus surpriz'd with humour.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: To which I'll undertake to adde some mirth.

sp.speaker: Euphor.
sp.p: Oh, oh! that kiss was a little too hard.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: He begins to speak now.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: You are mistaken Sir, 'twas I in him.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Nay, friends you have hugg'd sufficiently.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: Can a man make too much of himself Sir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I think he may! What say you, if it were vary'd with a dance?

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: With all my heart Sir.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: And mine, I was just thinking of it.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.p: Ta, ta, ta, ta, ta, ta.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: He could find in his heart to speak again.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: Now for the dance Sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You'l perform that doubly too.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p:
I'll assure you, I will; nay, I'll out do the imitation Of Dotterills in my double self—if I move
An Arm here—I move there another—
If a leg, my same leg answers me again in his:
To which purpose you shall see me dance.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: Let me be a witness to this miracle I beseech you, Since I am not beholding to my invention for a greater.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha. There's no containing from laughter, Was there ever such an Antique as this?

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: I think not.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen, thanks for our Mirth.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: You should have more, but that I have some desires To with-draw thus, and make much of my self.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: And I have occasions of some concern.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: To know of one Almanack-maker or other when the Moon will rise: farewel, farewel.
sp.stage: Ex. Peac. and Euphor. hugging: and Fopp. gazing Ex.
Enter Sir Grave Solymour and Celinda, in discourse.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Who's this, my Father leading of Celinda—

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Sir Grave Solymour handing of a fair Lady. Who could Have expected such an object amongst the rest?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And treads with such a demure Gravity as the Spaniard Does, when leading his woman to the next Couch, could I But prove him guilty of such a formal transgression.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Wee'l not interrupt them.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: By no means—but be sure Featlin thou fal'st on the rear Of him; I have something in the wind, I'd have thee smell out Further.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: I conceive you Sir, though the sight be not so welcome.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: All this exprest to me Sir?

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Call it my Justice Lady—who am not led by Common appetite to admire alone the beauties of your Face, but with it joyn your other vertues.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: For your complement I must thank you at least.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: I can explain my conceptions better: I do not find that in this Giddy world of womens rule, you have fill'd a seat of Magistracy in scorn of us that govern'd, or given the busy Tongues of men occasion to discourse.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: I live, Sir, free and innocent, I hope.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: It speaks your modesty and sober prudence, which renders you Fit to receive the addresses of my gravity, for which I'll so Far reconcile unto your sex, as to declare my self your Lover.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: I will not say I hate you for't; nor shall I much deny But that I live as you observe, enough reserv'd unto my Thoughts and privacy.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: And therefore fitter that your bosome close so grave a Secret as my love; I would not for my wealth, the vain And ruling women should report that in this hour of their Vanity, Sir Grave Solymour met with a Dart of Cupid, Or were toying with a Mistriss, though the delights of Venus Have a charm upon the stout, and wisest hearts, as unresisted By the Arm'd Souldier, as the States-man's gravity.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: A Gown-man that is willing to steal to a Petticoat—
Well Sir; I now conceive you fully.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Do, and enjoy me so.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: But as you are pleas'd to allow me your respects, and the Attribute of being wise, so it behoves me to consider.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: What, my fair Creature?

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: How and when to love you?

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Do my sweet; but let the time be short: Loves flames like Fire, devour themselves when too long smother'd.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: Besides our female Magistracy have not as yet resolv'd Upon their Laws of love; I suppose they intend to Make some.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Let them for themselves, but not for us, and would no Less become my gravity to consult their approbation; Wee'l be a Common-wealth unto ourselves, all delights Shall flow on thee to be bought with Gold, (which I Spare not to feed my secret pleasures;) my Jewels made Thy Ornaments and my self thy greater treasure—nay Look not on me as I am in years, or have a wrinckle on My brow.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: That's no wonder Sir, The Fox is gray before he's good.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: I can perform Lady, doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: By no means Sir—but what must I do to recompence This bounty?

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Love, and be secret.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: That's in my power I confess—but were you us'd to Exclaim so much against vanity, and have now such an Itchtowardsit.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: The cautious man will act, but hide his crime, 'tis wise Hypocrisy; which caus'd me often to blame mens levities And vainer inclinations which express those Symptomes of the Heart should be reserv'd: 'Tis scandal that makes sin, not Sin the scandal.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: A most solid piece of Lechery
I crave your pardon (Sir, I Thought Sin had been something more than a word.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: 'Tis so when scandalous and known, that even a God was Censur'd (as wiser Poets tell) being taken in embrace: Nature invites to secrecy, and all her operations acteth so, Which does instruct the cautious Deer to guide his soft and Amorous Hine unto some Covert to be there enjoy'd.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: A cautious way of concupiscence
well Sir, I perceive You want no manhood, and I'll touch it to the quick.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: With all my heart Lady.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: Then soberly thus, were you ever married?

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Some long time past.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: And have you not a Son?

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: I think I had one.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: And is he living?

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: I wish him so—and that's some blessing▪ I never did affect To dally with my Cradle, or the permitting of the expence That youth requires, parents that love themselves know How to be more provident; like to the Bird that early Does discharge her young ones from her care, and nest that bred Them—some small provision I have allow'd his education, And leave the rest unto his wit and fortune.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: A sober sort of ill nature—nor would you see him, perhaps Don't know him now.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Some Sixteen years have been elapsed since I beheld Him young, and sooner would I keep my Coffin in my Sight than him that hopes to be made happy by my death; Or with an evil eye, behold the riches I possess, of which He is not to partake; nay more, perhaps might envy or Oppose my will and choice, or think my love and bounty is Too great, although it purchase such an object as your self.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: Perhaps he might.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Let these assure you!
They are bright and Orient.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: No Sir, you shall keep your stones for some other time or Service! tho' I know well a present is one of the first, and most Considerable Expressions 'twixt servant and Mistriss—you are not In haste I know.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: No more, than what is proper for our loves, and hope you'l Soon deserve this, or a richer favour.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: When I do, I shall expect it.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: I like this answer well—and I'll be no less sparing of my Cost When I have enjoy'd her—a feat our Gallants practise
Often—But Lady, loves time is not so slow as that We tell, and all his Counsels like his acts should be swift And pleasant; too long a frost's unpleasant to the spring.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: The day is not far spent, altho' the first that dates Our body politick—some bus'ness does require me, Within an hour; you'l know more of my compliance.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Till when farewel: and remember 'tis loves prudence to Be secret.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: Doubt it not Sir.
Well polititian, if I do not fit your hot desires For this, may I lose my virginity to a Constable.
Mr. Featlin! you are come according to my wish, I Have such news to tell you.—

sp.speaker: Feat.
sp.p: As how prethee?

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: Why, I have such an interest in your father to do you Service, thou could'st not have wisht the like.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Perhaps I should not—.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: Thou would'st, since 'twill assure his favour, and what is (wanted More by the considerable part of his estate.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: It must be a strange Artifice can have the better of his Severity and covetousness.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: Leave it to me, I'll make him plyant as the Glove I wear, Be assur'd on't, as I wish thee well.—

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: I hope thou dost—But by what means?

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: By a common and easy Method, why man he loves me Abominably.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Is that a way to cure my sufferings? which must give a greater Wound, my fathers love to rival mine; all my afflictions. Summon'd could not have equall'd this.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: Be not suspicious but expect the end, 'tis that compleats An action.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: I fear too soon.
sp.stage: Enter Serina, Eugenia, Crispina, Petilla, with two other Ladies.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: But see, we are interrupted; I must apply my Self to our female Polititians.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Celinda!—false unto my Love—'t were strange,
But Riches are too oft Precedent when they Rival want,—Or perhaps some stratagem only of her wit, and so would Hold my thoughts suspended—I know not what to judge.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: Madam, we expected your assistence
In our Councels.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: Some affairs requir'd my absence which I hope you'l Pardon, nor do I want desires to serve the interest of Our fair Re-publick.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: We doubt it not—but now we are on a point Deserves it most, I mean of Love.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: A most necessary consideration.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: In order to which, I think fit it should be enacted that No man presume to make love first, except he be Commission'd by our Re-publick for that purpose.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: A just motion, and becomes our superiority.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: But where's our Modesty, if we begin to woe?

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: That's to be no Clause in our Act.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: Nor need it be our concern—there are some of us Can be as bold and ne'er blush for't.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Besides there is some state in restraining the bold Presumptions of men, in making their addresses To us with their caps, and knees, and frivolous Services; that we are sometimes not a little vex'd with Their importunities, and our habitations as much troublld. With these Spirits of love, as Women of pleasure are, That have too frequent visits from our Town Hectors,

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: There is some weight in this consideration.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: And will save fools the labour of making love.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Would I had prevented the Fopp my Husband That way too—but as the case stands, I do well Enough.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: I am for't—2. Lad.—And so am I.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And I indifferent.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: And so in hats, and feathers, a woeing shall we?

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: And boots and spurs too, if occasion requires; I'll have some in readiness on purpose.

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p: And so have I.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: But Ladies a little moderate this decree, and as men Have had the superiority in love, and marriage; let Them be the first Movers still, and you the last.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: No, no, wee'l begin and end too.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: A Common-wealth of love towards indeed.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: But if this violence continue I shall be soon Weary of my office.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Then for another consideration, of which we Wives are Not a little sensible—which is, the Abilities of men.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: How mean you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: I mean internal, and external, I have some reason To move for both.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: As likewise a Consideration of the old, and fusty pieces Of antiquity, who have such reliques of their sinful Youth, as they will offer at love in spight of nature.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Out upon 'em, let's banish them our Common-wealth.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: That were too extreme as the other's immodest.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: By your favour no more, than if I bargain for a pair Of Gloves, I look whether they are handsome and well Made; or on a horse, and consider whether he be sound Of wind and limb: besides, Innumerable objections Which are not convenient, or decent to be made, but as We give private Judgment.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: Besides that, it is a just retaliation of the Intrigue which men are bold to hold with our Waiting-women and Chamber-Maids, to discover If possible, our least imperfections.

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p:
As whether we have sweet Breaths, good teeth, and the Hair that we wear our own, or in what part
Wanted, nay will question our very complexions too, That we cannot use a small Fucus without their discourse And Censure, and so have a Jury of their wits sit upon Every feature about us.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Perrhaps Lampoon us and our Husbands when they have Done.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: In so much as we cannot receive Court-ships, keep our Decorums, formalities, and state, as we should do.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Or be suffer'd to grow old in quiet for them.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: That's a hard case believe me.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: A most insupportable one.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: Ladies, this is too womanish, and violent—let me moderate.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: I could find in my heart not to hear reason in their Behalf.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: Nor I, except I like it, or such as may be superseded By our wills, when we find occasion.

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p: Spoke like a Common-wealths woman.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Nay we must hear our Precedent.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: By any means.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: Then mark what I propose—say, we appoint women Commissioners, who shall satisfie your desires with Prudence and modesty.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: That word Modesty may be prejudicial.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: I mean such as shall pass due Censure on the humours, Inclinations and other qualifications of men; giving us Information accordingly.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: This sounds discreet.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And of Latitude enough.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: I was never against it.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Nor I, nor I, nor I.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: And so give us a list of those who are fit to make love, Marry, or continue still Platonicks.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: For Platonicks; my vote is to strike them out of The Particular, as Drones that would have the Hony Of Courtship and do nothing for it.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: By any means.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: They shall be excepted then—and for the rest wee'l Have our inquiries that shall be sufficient.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: Let it be effectuall, and speedy.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p:
It shall be done to day, though the first of our
Government.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: To day, to day, to day:

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: And the last of my being your Precedent, Ladies, If this mood hold.

div.head: The Fourth Act.
div.stage: The Scene opens with two Pillars with decrees on them on both sides the Stage.
Enter Sir Adam Meridith and Frankman.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: WEll, Frankman, here are pretty decrees legible: I Believe we have yet a more jocund world towards—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Let it come and welcome; but methinks this clause sticks In a tender place of me, Meridith: not to make love Without a dispensation; or except such as are pleas'd to be our Mrs. give the onset First, I did not expect such limitations from this fair Re-publick.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Better, and better, by my love and manhood, to see them Bestow their addresses first, and Cry, Your humble Lady ready To serve you, how well you look to day, would I might Be so happy to be preserv'd in your thoughts, and the like Dallyings we use to them, which will be such a pleasant Inversion of our amours, there's nothing can parallel it.—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Nay, I believe 'twould puzzle a better Poet than ever writ Of the Art of loving: for my part, if we 'scape a Jury of Women with Spectacles commission'd to make a survey of Us naked, 'Tis more than I look for.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Let the Bona Roba's do what they please, I am without and Within the same.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: There's no superiority to be expected but lying uppermost, And that I suppose they will allow us.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Who have we here?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: The noble Polidor—but the world's alter'd since he left Us a Common-wealth of men.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Most noble Sir! your arrival's welcome here.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Exceeding welcome!

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: I thank you kindly—and since I parted from this Countrey on the publick service, I find our State Has suffer'd no small Metamorphosis in changing of Our Sex that govern'd.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: They claim'd it as their right.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: I think they might, although we have but few Records can shew the practise, which tells us that The women of this age have more confidence than their Sex had formerly.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: For my part Sir, I could not find in my heart to Contest against the government of Ladies.—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Besides here was such a Caterwauling with the whole sex, And their Talons of power so egregiously manifested On some visages of our over-wiv'd Citizens, till they yielded Their Necks to their Yoak, that there was no withstanding.—

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: I cannot blame them to submit, if the assault was so Fierce.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Many of us could not chuse but smile, and let it pass.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And I amongst the rest; tho' the experience I have had In the world might prompt me otherwise, the youth I Find about me did forbid it.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: You preserve your franck humour still, Sir?

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Rather encrease it—I should be loth that in the last Scene of my life whensoever it comes, my spirits should Fall.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: And who are the most remarkable Politicians?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why, every mans Wife and Daughter in their several capacities.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: Their Husbands cannot chuse but fare wel then.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
I suppose they have not beheaded any of them yet,
Though they make bold to cut off their intails. It may be They will draw up new Indentures with others shortly if Cause require.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: A strange revolution of things.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: To which purpose I expect love should be made to My self by some of them.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: Are they to begin then?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: 'Tis a Decree fix'd here, and in most Streets; at one Of which places I observ'd a woman pictur'd in a hat And Feather, Booted, and Spurr'd, ready to take her wooing Progress.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And was it not pleasant?

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: As a Novelty I confess, and 'tis odds but some of them Will put on Arms, and make War shortly.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Were not our men too kind to give them the trouble.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: Or for want of enemies fight with one another.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Such as take upon them to be the chief Patronesses of Their Re-publick are the Ladies, Serina, Crispina, Eugenia.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: Serina too! I thought she had been without this ambition.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Some did expect as much, but Power has no few Idolaters of that Sex amongst their other superstitions.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: How does she carry it?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: With moderation becoming a Lady of her Birth, and in All extreams as much as in her lies tempers the rest. In So much that were this monstrous Democracy of ours Transform'd into Monarchy, she might deserve to be A partaker in the Throne.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: It speaks her worth.
Here Comes Serina.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And with her Celinda, an ingenious Lady.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: In some discourse, wee'l wait their leisure—

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: Is't possible he should attempt your vertue?

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: With as much zeal as if I had spread my Art for him.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: And yet would have the world believe otherwise, Which gain'd him such an exemplary repute Of a sober Magistrate with the vulgar.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: But Madam, there are many Maxims of Hypocrisy With such Polititians as are, or would be in power, While Covetousness or some few Grains of amorous Concupiscence betrays their frailty: Let the world be govern'd By Common-wealths, or Princes, 'tis odds that one or both Of these vices will have some Predominance.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: I hope 'twill not be so, whilst Women rule; besides this Action of Sir Grave Solymour offends the law we have Establish'd, which says, that men should not begin their Courtships to us.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: And especially when they offer them the wrong way; could I devise some just punishment for him, I hope the Act Would be excus'd by our Re-publick.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: It shall have my vote at least—if not to inlarge It, if Cause shall require.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: That does my bus'ness.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: I perceive that Polidor's return'd.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: But this day—By your leave Madam.—

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: Serina, I was just wishing an opportunity to wait On you, which you now prevent.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: I am little more reserv'd than when I saw you last.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: But power in women, as well as love, will have its Distance.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: I never acted yet the Tyrants part, nor shall begin With you.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: I know you are Gracious.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: Such thoughts can only elevate the mean of Man-kind That forget themselves and duties when rais'd to greatness; I do not curle a lock the more because our Sex does Govern—And so farwell Sir.—

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Short and sweet.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But I hope 'twill not end so.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: Nay Madam! you must not part thus—you'll Remember I am Polidor.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: And that's as much as I think sit to do at this time, If you offer more, you know our Law—

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: By your fair self.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: Take heed Sir how you swear, we have lately made a Law Against Lovers Oaths, and Perjuries—but to assure you I Forgive you—

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: May I have your hand for't.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: Yes, and lead me by it—but if you offer at love—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I hope she'l save him the labour and begin, According to our new mode of wooing.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: If she does not doe as much as that comes to, She's not such flesh and blood, I take her for.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Her Extraction's eminent, and his (if well examin'd) From our antient Stock of Princes, and should they But mix souls kindly, what a change might this Various state of ours receive?

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: As I wish men and women well, it should have My consent.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: By your favours Gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Peacock, is it you? and where's your other Self Euphorbus?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Perhaps he has made his transmigration into Some other body already.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: I left him Sir behind (that's I in him) to deliver a Message, I thought fit to express my self.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Such a Consubstantian as this would exceed all Pythagorical wonder, and belief.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: But to be serious.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And such a jest present as thy self.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: O here comes his other Manhood.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: By your leave a little Gentlemen, I must First make much of my absent self before I Acquaint you with my bus'ness.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Was there ever such a hugging as this?

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.p: O, O, O,—my Mouth, my Eye, my Ear will be kiss'd off.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And 'twere in his belly, I dare say hee'd digest it.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Did you not hear his tonge wagg even now?

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: Who! I hear my self! I hope I do.—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And so bitterly, that I believe there's Tears in's eyes yet.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: I'd have you to know, I am no whining Lover, tho' this Be my self Lover.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: This had been a humour to have entertain'd Democritus.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Or rather that other Philosopher that wept for the folly of men. But Sir—to your desire, we are in haste.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: And mine is a nimble question—I desire to be resolv'd Whether in this womanish state of ours (as I would be Some Novelty amongst the rest) you hold it requisite that We who are two in one should make love together Likewise.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: A very pertinent question!

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And would put the most serious Ladies of our Countrey To a smile to answer.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: In my judgment your best way will be to make Your applications to that Sex, who can better resolve you: Though I believe if you can make your double unity Good, you may not be unwelcome to some.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: Suppose then you were the Lady, I would kiss My hand thus—and so in him.—
Then sir, when I presume to the Cheek, as I do To yours.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Hold, hold I prethee.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: And for this old Youths likewise,—I would do thus!

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And shalt for that word, and welcome too, if there were Ten of thee more.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Away, away, that I may wipe my mouth In quiet.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: And if I meet with an Amour I will kiss her as I am One, and for the rest I will perform it as I am two, that Is to say twice in once.—

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Well, Frankman, thou hast been a little guilty With this Mountebanck Virtuoso of this extravagancy.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I confess it, being willing to inflict some punishment On his folly, it being a Sin that is ever best corrected By it self.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: See here comes Sir Grave Solymour.—with his Codds Head in querpo—one that I abominate as my Antipathy in Age, or a Satyr against mirth.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I conceive you—and tho' he seems in haste Shall we stay him, and tease him a little?

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Till he fret himself to death, for Meridith.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You shall give the first onset, Sir Adam.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Content, content.
And whither in such haste good Grave Sir.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: I suppose you have nothing to do to examine me.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Not your bus'ness if I could guess it. However I'll Presume to tell you that I wonder you have not yet Took up your stand underone of yonder pillars, And there made your exclamations against vanity, where I assure you Sir, are things worth your perusal,

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: I know it, I know it; but impose not on my thoughts At this time!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: There's not such a contrariety betwixt any of the Elements As is in the dispositions of these two pieces of Antiquity, And no less pleasant to observe.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: By my troth Sir, but that you are a man of patience, I might have expected you had come to have hang'd Your self yonder.—

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Good Sir, leave me, I have urgent occasions.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: I mean to give you Counsel for your good, Sir.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Me Counsel, Sir?

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: I say you, Sir,—and tell you plainly the dangers you may Incurre, if you do not immediately lay aside your stiff Formality, set speeches against Sin; in order to your Conformity with our female Government.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: I will be chang'd into an Hermophrodite rather, And be slave to both Sexes at once—but I remember I am in haste, Sir.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: But take good speed along with you Sir, and as you Are kind to your self, be gay, sportly; Hawk, Hunt, Sing, Dance, and strive to cut Capers, as I can, and will To instruct you—
Now Frankman Do thou give him t'other heat—I know thy wit is ready On all occasions.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: To save your Lungs a labour, Sir, I'll do my best.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Another Comical Satyrist to fall on me?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You may make Mirth on't, if you please, Sir.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p:
What do you mean by thus irritating me Mr. Frankman?
Or has any of the Predominant Ladies Given you commission to abuse me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: So Grave a man as you are, restrain'd from the Enjoyments of flesh and blood—I cannot blame you to be mov'd Sir, nay though You curs'd a little, I think the Crime might be Forgiven you.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Rather let us pray for them.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You mean as some Professors do, whose Satyrical Devotion may pass for Execration and pray'r together.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Good Sir, no more.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: In the mean time, give me leave to hint you a little.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Hint me to pray, Sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Only some general notions to be added to your Letany.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: So you will cease this molestation of me, I am Content that you Curse, nay Curse effectually all Woman Kind.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Of this Common-wealth you mean?

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Not one to be exceped—but such I design To enjoy.—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: As for example, that to spight their future pleasure There might be no procreation with their help: But rather that posterity might be continu'd as easily As Fly-blowings, or come together by chance like Epicurus's Atoms—this had been an execration on Their Re-publick indeed.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Enough, enough, Sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Or in stead thereof (if you think fit) that every member Of it be debauch'd by the men they govern—have I hit you there Sir?

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: As it is their desert I comply—Let that suffice at This time, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You have done pretty well I confess.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: I know it, nor shall it be mention'd to your prejudice By me, and so farwell Grave Sir.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: This Scene of vexation was pleasant.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I had ends in't: come, I'll tell thee more as we walk, And next to acquain Featlin.—

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p:
I cann't but smile in spight of my temper To think how this Satyrical compliance of
Mine against women, will render me unsuspected In my Amorous design—He that knows not How to dissemble, knows not how to live, was a Wise Apothegme of the Antients; and I'll adde, to Love with dexterity and free from the Scandal of Tongues: He that purchases a Mistress, buyes love at His own rate, but he that marries, rather sells himself—Celinda must be just, and no less private In my reception; since beneficial Interest does Oblige it, the surest tye of love; which must yield Me a revengful pleasure in the enjoyment Of so fair a member of this Anti-common-wealth. But yet me thinks I find some fears about me, Like a man that intends a theft within sight of The Gallows.—
sp.stage: Enter Celinda vail'd, but puts it up when she sees Sir Solymour.
sp.p: But here she is—Posts by Your leave.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: Dispatch Sir, dispatch.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: I was hasting to thee, but that I met with an Interruption, I could have curs'd by the way—And are we secure and quiet?

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: Without noise so much as the falling of a Mousetrap.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Excellent, fair one, I thank my stars and thee.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: And I mine as much, for conspiring to do our loves Justice, I'll lead you the way.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: To a part of thy bed I hope.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: You are right Sir, but it shall receive You by day to avoid suspicion.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: A safe device—Come, thou shalt be my downe there, I need no other softness—my Imagination's on Fire till I enjoy thee.—

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: It must be she; I know it by her voice—and in My Fathers hand, in whose address to her consists A higher injury than my being so long neglected and Forgotten in his thoughts,—what's my Misfortune!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: O here's Featlin! What in a fit of Melancholly! And in such days as these! fy man—fy—.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: O that Father of mine.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Would he were marry'd to a Gypsy, provided his Estate were thine.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: I thought my afflictions gentle, until confirm'd That Celinda did receive his addresses.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But I have turn'd the tide I warrant thee, and put him In such a hideous apprehension of the Superscription of these objects, and his danger,

That hee'l as soon hang on one of them as proceed, For thy further security; and so aggravated the matter, As I made him as good as curse Mothers, Wives, and Daughters, together with their whole Re-publick.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: But what's all this to me, when this very minute He was receiv'd by Celinda.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Art' sure on't?

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Or my Sense fails me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And did I hope! If not, the Common-wealth of Jury Had never such a Pharisee, and Publican together as He is.—

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: I wish I could deny it justly.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Mr. Frankman and Mr. Featlin, My Lady Celinda Desires the presence of you both, with what speed You may, in her Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: What's the bus'ness?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: A Womans, you know what that means.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Then 'tis love.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: And marriage together it may be. Sir Grave Solymour was just ending with a Sack-possit As I came to you.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Did not I tell you?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: A mischief on her if it prove true, Featlin.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: You'l be there Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: 'Tis like we may.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: And if you please, invite some other of your friends.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: This is strange! and yet methinks I
Like well that we are to be present—Courage Featlin; there must be good some way or other Towards thee.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: I know not what to think!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Celinda's wise, and love has many Intrigues; think No more, but follow me.—

div.stage: The Scene opens and discovers a Bed.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: HEre lyes Celinda, the treasure of whose beauty I must now possess, and 'tis my riches she'd enjoy: but I'll deceive her there: however Gold I thank thee; thou Art indeed the God of love, and Poets did mistake thy Charmes, whilst they forgot in thy refulgent shape to Paint their Venus and their Cupid; since thou can'st Beauty win to be thy prostitute, and vertue captive tho'
sp.stage: [Moor moves in the Bed. pulls off his Gown.
sp.p: Immur'd like Danaa—she stirs—and I must stir her Too.—Ly thou there—Gown—And with thee I put off my gravity. The Monarch or the Magistrate can keep but little State in these enjoyments, where the Peasant and the beggar's Part's the same with theirs, Since 'tis our natures highest Comedy—
sp.stage: As he undraws the Curtains, the Moor puts forth her head.
sp.p: Ha! my hopes are blasted in this spectacle. Some evil Spirit or Devil to punish my Hypocrisy.
What shall I do to secure my shame and safety?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You need not fear Sir, and so many of your friends. Ready to serve you.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: I am glad of this, I 'faith, Sir Solymour, I see you can Be amorous at your years as well as I at mine.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Was there ever such an unwelcome salutation. Oh my Torment!—

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: I wonder Gentlemen! by what authority you presume To disturb our intended embrace.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: This is no dumb Devil I perceive.—

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: For my part I'd have you to know, I mean nothing But what is honourable to this worthy Knight; as I Hope to be my Lady Solymour, 'tis true Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: How! my Lady! Night-hag.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: It seems a contract.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: And wanted nothing but consummation.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: Which you have rudely hinder'd, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Nay, you shall compleat your bus'ness if you Please, the World knows I never lov'd to spoil Sport.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: As you are men, have so much mercy on me As to permit I 'scape out of this snare I am Got in.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: That's impossible! the Doors are all lock'd Or guarded.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: And by women too!

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: What would you have Gentlemen, I confess my Folly deserves a Curse as lowd as all their Tongues Can express together.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Perhaps they may teaze you a little.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Or meet in a full cry of their body politick, That were sport indeed.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And Lady you had best be ready to receive them.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: I shall, Sir, with all expedition.—
sp.stage: She conveys her self out of the bed.
Enter Foppering with his half-Moon on his head.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Herè comes Tom Foppering, I took a course he Should not fail.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: He come too?

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: No less than the man in the Moon I assure you Sir.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Good Sir, what has the earth or I to do with him Then, let him go to his fellow subjects in t'other World I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Now it works.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: I hope to good purpose.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And canst thou make good this fiction?

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: A fiction Sir! upon my sincerity a miracle.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And shall we take thy word for it?

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: If you know where to have a better proof for a Miracle than ones word comes to, you may get it Where you can, however you shall have no more For this.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Come to an end, Tom.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: Why I'll tell you Sir, as you know I wish her highness Well, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: The story of her slipper we have heard already; but this Of her face should imply a greater Prodigy.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: To tell you true Gentlemen, as I was now calculating Her motions from the top of my house, she was Pleas'd to slip off this face of hers and put it upon mine, In the same manner you see it.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: An Astronomical Liar too!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: There are none greater, if their calculations were well Observ'd.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: Since Copernicus his time or before she hath not vouchsaf'd Such a favour to any man—As I hope to finish the Other part of her calculation, 'tis true Sir.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Let me never know mirth if I believe thee not in that.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And then you are to receive the other Part of her face, are you not?

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: What else Sir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: How like you this Dialogue Sir Solymour?

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Would I were not the greater Fool.—

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: Joy, joy, transcendent joy, Sir; you are wish'd it both By the Moon and I abundantly.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: What do you mean Bedlam?

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: To salute your happy inclinations; I did not believe That so Grave a man as your self would have honour'd Love, these days of frailty—but since you are In that predicament.—

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: What then Sir?

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: Why, I have put on my Moon as you see on purpose To wait on you.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Gentlemen, perswade his Silence—I shall be mad too Else, before he has done with me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible, he will have his run.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: Besides my design in giving you a visit at your lodging With four Drums, six Trumpets, and a Consort of 22 Violins With Flutes, Recorders and Dulcimores.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: To be bated thus with a Lunatick! A cry of Hounds Were Musick to't.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: And next, Sir, I will have a Ballad sung on This subject to salute your Love, and you, in the morning, I know a ten Groat Poet shall compose it.

sp.speaker: Soly
sp.p: Methinks your years should teach you Compassion.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Who! I, old Sir! who has youth then?—go on a little For that Ladel.—

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: No Sir, here's one shall divert him—The Lady, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: This entrance is worse than all the rest.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: As I am a servant of the Moons, and she a Lady of the Night and love, I wish you happy.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: I thank you Sir, Though I could desire of Heaven (might it be granted) that my complexion were some-What more Grateful, to this Knight my Lover.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: O Monstrous! she calls me Lover too!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And you'l prove her to want no flame I'll warrant her: There's AEthiopia Sir on t'other Side of the Tropick you are to pass.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: I have heard those Sun-burnt females are most Delicious in embrace.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Are they so Sir?

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And have the spring within them, though they want It without.—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: If you get a Mag-py Child (as there may be some Danger) I'll invite my self Gossip.
sp.stage: Enter Petilla, Celinda and two Ladies more.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And I your Partner.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: I thank you Gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: If you have mercy and are men, spare me.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: Then for her Complexion, it resembles my Mistriss The Moon's, when in an Ecliptick Conjunction. For which cause I like it better than that white Meager Face of my Wives.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Do you so, Sir?

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: These she Teazers come to encrease the Cry,

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: Contain! let me perswade you.
sp.stage: Fopp. plays at bopeep behind them.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: You shall till convenient time.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: Let me skreen my self behind you Gentlemen By turns.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But take care your Moon be not seen.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: I'll do my endeavour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: And for you most abominable Sir, an infringer of Our most sacred law of love by making your Lascivious attempt on this Lady.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: Putting aside the punishment you deserve in being a Sober ill example, like a malicious secluded member Of our late Government.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: As also of a Hyppocrite and Sinner together.

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p: And more ill natur'd and Covetous than a Jew of Our new Synagogue.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: Then for a Father, I'll witness, he is little Inferior to Herod.—

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: What a Nest of Hornets have I stir'd?

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p:
For which you are censur'd by our body politick To espouse this beautiful Black, which the hand.
Of Fortune presents to your embrace.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: O me! the stings of all your Satyrs meet in this.—Did you say, marry her?

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: Or which is all one, you are concluded Man and Wife Already.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: That was the Close I look'd for.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I conceive thee.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Is there no remedy?

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: Not except you hang your self.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Madam, I must thank you for this.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: I did it to have you beholding to me As you'l find; in the mean time, to deceive the Deceiver has some excuse.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Well, Solymour, it has been thy fate, notwithstanding All thy policy, to heighten the part of a cautious Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And so I give you joy.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And I by my Manhood could bestow some Capers On this day of Hymen.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: I'll excuse your Mirth, Sir.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: Ladies, I thank your justice.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Impudent above her complexion too.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: But it must not end thus—and have I found you—thou Moon Calf—thou?

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: Save me Ladies, and Gentlemen—or as thou art A good Common-wealth's Woman have mercy on A Citizen.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Were I not so, you should feel my Fingers!—.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: Oh, Oh, Oh.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: You should Sir.—

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: I do, I do! nothing but the fingers of a Fairy Could pinch so deep.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Indeed Sir.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: Good Queen Mabb spare me.—

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Must I be a Lady of Dominion and have a Husband Call'd the man in the Moon, must I?—

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: I meant my self thy man, and thou the Moon all the while, Wife; that is by way of Metaphor.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p:
You had best tell how many embraces you have Given me more than I requir'd, and so for Manhood
Sake bely us both; or feign I have more servants Than really I have, and call it Metaphorical, you Had Sir?

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: But pardon Metaphor I beseech thee for Love's Sake, and Poetry.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Well, Sir, as I am favourable to Poetry, I'll pardon Your fictions at this time; so as your fools fire produce No more.—

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: I'll have nothing to do with the best Moon that Ever shin'd since thou wilt have it so; and yet Methinks this affront might have been spar'd to Cynthia, Under Correction—Madam.—

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Withdraw Sir, and know I expect your further submission.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Away, away, whilst the storm ceases.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: Since a man cannot be believ'd who can help it.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: An over-wife, tho' a little one—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And were I her Husband, I should be in love with The Moon in earnest before her.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Pardon me Madam, that my respects were Interrupted by that necessary rebuke I gave that Titular thing call'd my Husband—but hope the Example may be of good use, as you may have Occasion to exercise your matrimonial Dominion

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: The Counsel of a Fury added to my affliction.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: I shall lose no prerogative that becomes a Wife Or a member of your Re-publick.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: For Which you may deserve a signal respect.
