sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: More Birds of a Feather to gaze at my folly.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Nothing but a brace of Peacocks for the last Course, Sir.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Would there were a limb of one of them in your Belly; I shall be whoop'd at by every Owl before They have done with me.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: An odd sight.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: I have heard of his humour before—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
Nay, blame me Sir, rather, since I must Acknowledge I caus'd them to come hither to present
Their respects to you, and your Lady.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Did you so, Sir?

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: And art thou the sprightly Black the Lady of Night And beautiful blossom of darkness?

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, blossom of darkness.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: The Bride of this Gravity's, and Sister of Hymens.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: He has rais'd her descent, Sir, something for your sake.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: O the perplexity I am in—a night of Cynthia's Revels In which all the Lunaticks are at liberty.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Be resolute Sir and stand the worst.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Would I were dead, or any thing to be freed.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: I am glad to hear it.—

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: Had I but known this night of joy sooner, I would Have been doubly feather'd, as you see I am in him And he in me.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.p: And I likewise, as I am two in him, and he two in me, am At your service.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: The Miracle encreases now.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: As far as they please to believe it.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: An Insinitum of vexation.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: And next I would have been at thy service in as Many Capacities—that is thus for me, and thus for Him.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.p: And thus for me, and thus for him.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: As here's one lip, there's t'other—and so likewise for The rest of these Ladies.—

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: We are beholding to you Sirs, as I am a Wife.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: I thank you Gentlemen, and as you are mine in several Respects, I will be as many times yours.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: O my fate, I shall wear a horn, and caus'd by so Sooty a Sinner as this.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: And be glad if you scape so Sir.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: But that we are merciful and pitty failings, you Had been worse dealt with.
sp.stage: Enter Polidor, Serina, Eugenia, Crispina, and several Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Saly.
sp.p: Is that possible.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: Ladies all your pardons, I have Perform'd my Devoirs, and so I doubly take my leave.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.p: And I as doubly too.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: Farwell, pair of Wonders—

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: You have pass'd a severe sentence on this Knight.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: I thought it justice to consent considering every Circumstance.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: You are just in all things.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: I should be sorry, Sir, if the publick or you have Cause to complain of the power I possess—tho' at This time I shall propose something may concern you, Please you observe a space.—

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: What does she mean?—

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.p: As sure as I live, Serina is beginning her address To Polidor, by vertue of our late Decree.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: What if she does, I suppose Cupid has more use Of his Darts, than to aim only at her—tho' I confess Polidor, for a man, is a mark indeed.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: Our President, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: More of their Clamours yet!

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: I hope not so, Sir.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: Nor needs it Lady Solymour.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Was ever man marry'd thus?

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: You own the Decree, Ladies?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: All, all.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: And next you may withdraw with your Lady, Sir.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Must I hand her too? No, she shall have but one of My fingers.—

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: I'll take hold of the longest finger then.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Take Comfort, Sir, however.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Hast thou any to give me?

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: I shall be sorry not to my endeavours as occasion Serves—I perceive he does not know me yet.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: And be near him to proceed as we shall advise.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: I understand thee, dear Celinda.—

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: For other irregularities of men that Concern our Sex, we may proceed against them As cause shall require.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: And for such as have Wives, to make it more Enormous, if they presume to begin their Amours First; In good faith I was thinking to have brought In a charge against mine.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Though she has pinch'd him to purpose—as we Can witness.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And for nothing but pretending he is in love with The Moon.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: But that I could not be so severe, with the frailties Of a man, I have receiv'd services from.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: And what shall we decree against such, that Intrigue by the way of servants, and yet as perfidious To their Mistresses as any Husband of 'em-all

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Say we establish a High Court of Justice of Love?

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: That were a new way of acting Tyrannick love indeed?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But I hope no Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: I am not against it; provided, we do men and our selves Right, by insisting on merit, and such other perfections As are justly ours.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: You have spoken my sence, Madam.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: I do not like so well that word, Merit.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: No matter, Madam, you have Beauty.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: And should be sorry to quit my fair interest, did I Stand for a Venus with the proudest she living.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: In the mean time behold what I present to your Considerations, a Catalogue of Lovers according to the Inquiry of our women Commissioners.
sp.stage: They view all the Paper earnestly.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: An ingenious accompt.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: And suitable to our instructions.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: If there be any here you think well on, you may Bestow a look on him if you please.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Our President should have the liberty to begin first.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: By any means, Madam.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: I am fix'd already: but I'll lead you the way.
sp.stage: The Women walk round the men. Crispina, Petilla, 1 Lady, eyeing Frankman, Celinda, and 2d Lady eye others, while Eugenia eyes Meridith more strictly than any of the rest of the Men.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Nay Ladies not too many of your beams Together.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: The more the merrier.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: If I mistake not Ladies, too many of your kind Aspects have been particularly united on some deserving Objects here.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: I know where I look'd first.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: And so do I, by your favour Madam,—I hope the Eye of a Wife may be as well understood as e'r A Virgins of you all.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: And I remember where I look'd too.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And so do I!—

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: That look meant me Frankman.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I perceive it.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: And I forget not whom I beheld.
sp.stage: Celinda looks carelesly on the men.

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p: And I by your leave, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: This is Mirth indeed Frankman.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: A pleasant sort of Loves lightning, and some of us must Be his Thunderbolts it seems.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: But Ladies, how will you determine betwixt Your selves, in Case that several of you affect one Man?

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Why, in that case we may decree him a publick lover.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: That were a particular injury.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: No matter so it be a publick good, by your favour, Madam.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Rather, let us establish a High Court of Justice Of love to determine our differences.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: I look'd for this.—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: There's no reason for a dissenter.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: I am for it.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: And I.—Omn.—And all.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: And I comply as willingly.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: And when shall our High Tribunal of love meet?

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: In some minutes under an hour! You have Your summons to appear, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: I dare promise for all, that we will not fail you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: God a mercy, thou sinner of Sixty.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: A lively piece of antiquity.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: The design takes to my wish; how do you Like it Polidor?

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: 'Tis such a novelty, Madam, I know not how To judge it handsomely.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: Leave it to me—

lg.l: Nor do I doubt our Stars will be unkind.
Since Love has yet more Wonders left behind.

div.head: The Fifth Act.
div.stage: The Scene resembles a Tribunal of Love.
Enter Serina, Crispina, Eugenia, Celinda, Petilla, and 2 Ladies.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: I Hope, Ladies, you have sufficiently implor'd the Humorsome God of Love to compose your differences.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I can answer for my self, and hope well of the rest.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: I doubt not your Modesty.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: But we expect it shall not diminish the least part Of our State and interest.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: As I am a Wife I am oblig'd to do no less, hoping to Have the Vote of all this fair Society in my behalf.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: We shall not dissent.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: But to do justice on your selves now, will be the Difficulty; since in my thought your Eyes met too Particularly, as you beheld the men: and it were strange if A common-wealth should not have variety enough for So many Women as we are here.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I judg so, Madam.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: The persons that fall under present Consideration, will be these Gentlemen here, Though a small Number of the Catalogue.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p:
For Mr. Frankman, Madam, I dare answer for the Language of my Eye, so far, as to acknowledge him
A deserving Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: But by your favour, Lady, I have had him in my thoughts Ever since I was a Wife.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: And I ever since I was a Virgin.

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p: I would say something too, Madam,—but let that pass.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: And for Mr. Featlin here, what woman can have the heart Not to think well of him.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: And such a neat built man as he is.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: And what say you to this, Celinda?

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: I'll leave him to the best pretender, Madam,—my Love shall not go farther than my wit is able to Make it good.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: We are now under Censure i'faith Boys.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And if they disable me from being a lover, my years Have ill luck.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: I wonder that Celinda's justice has not found me yet.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: O, their thoughts are so full of universals, there's no Room for a particular Amour yet.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: And what for this Grave Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: He shall have our Supersedeas, if he please.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Or to recreate him, let him be our general Platonick?

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: And so have our society at times of eating; I have Heard he's pleasant.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Methinks he might deserve better.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: And think so still if you please.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Dost' hear this Meridith?

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: I do, and smile at their mistake,—I their Platonick?

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: And then for Polidor.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: He too within your ayms?

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: The most accomplish'd person in our Common-wealth, Why is he not here?

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: I long to survey him.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: But I had him in my eye before you, Lady: by My Membership of this State, we have not justice President, and a man wanting we think well of.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: This sounds too much of Anarchy in love, the worst Of Mischiefs to all humane Government.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: But practis'd under all we conceive, Madam.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: A Wives condition were a severe one otherwise.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: It shall never have my vote.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Nor mine, Serina.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: As it may Authorize dishonest actions, I likewise do defy It; but as I love my wit, my beauty, or take pride to be Respected (a pardonable frailty in our Sex) I'd have It paid me too as many ways—A woman may be A Saint of Loves, and yet have more than single Adoration.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: By my life, brave, and witty.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: She has it in abundance, man.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: You may be allow'd your sence, Crispina, but till you Better reconcile—Serina, is no more your President Celinda!—

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Serina is with-drawn in discontent, And Celinda with her.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I did expect it, and guess which way the stream of things Are bending.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: This breach was sudden.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: No matter, we may proceed without her.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Or chuse another in her stead.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your patience-and your counsel, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: The Ladies are in consultation about us.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Perhaps they will chuse us by lots or else play us together Like a battle Royal of Cocks.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: But I have design'd my match otherwise, if Fortune Be not peevish and hinder me.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: In the mean time, let us sing, three Merry Boys, and three merry Boys, and three merry Boys are we.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Here comes Foppering—but I'll fright him away—Hark you Tom.—

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: What's the matter Sir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Strange matters are in handling by the women, Tom.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: But I desire to have nothing to do with their hands or fingers.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I know thou wouldst not, Tom.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: I had only an extraordinary complement to have Presented their High Court of love, and thought to Have ask'd your advice whether I may Presume to except my Wife.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Thou shalt not have to do with her, or them, at present. And for thy Wife, she is in such a Mood.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: Let her go whistle above or below then.—I'll not Make much of her now.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: She is at present like Tow, ready to take fire with The least spark of passion.—Away, away,—I would Not have thee seen.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: And is she angry, say you then?—Why then I'll not Provoke her so much as by my submission now; She shall be pleas'd better first.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Be gone, I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: But if you can intercede for my humiliation or so; you Conceive me Sir,—and you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Some other time wee'l undertake it.

sp.speaker: Fopp.
sp.p: I thank you heartily, Sir, and in gratitude will tell You a more extraordinary tale, than I have told you yet.—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Enough, enough.—

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And well we are rid of him, I was apprehensive that His Mirth might have prevented a better expected.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Not to proceed, were a diminution of our privilege, And might teach men to neglect our Authority, or what Is worse, to slight our loves.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: I am resolute in the cause.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: But I hope with modesty.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: Crispina shall be our Speaker.

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p: And so avow our prerogative by her mouth; she'l manage It like a Town-wit I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Indeed Ladies! and a Wife of the Re-publick in place?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: With your leave, Madam.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: They have decreed to assault us now.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And I'll charge them as home, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Then by my leave you may.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: But it shall be to defeat your intrigue, if my Wit does not deceive me.—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: They have chosen a Speaker to my wish, and I am prepar'd For her.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Suppose, Gentlemen, that some of us should resolve to Express our good opinion of you. I do not mean you.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: What you please, Madam.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p:
Or that you Mr. Frankman were the man I bid to
Love me?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why, in that oase, Madam, I would answer the supposition By another supposition; as, supposing that any of These Ladies were your Rivals, and that you design'd Me for your self, which Heaven avert from your Thoughts

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: Mark that, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Nay Mr. Frankman will deal with'em well enough I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: How! Heaven avert it, say you so, Sir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Marry do I, and dare swear it before your Tribunal Of Love too, if you please.—How Madam! Command my love?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: I put it to you as a Supposition, Sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why then, Lady, you must unsppose again—ha, ha, ha, Bid me love? why, 'tis scarce within the Power of The Stars to command it.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: You dare not, Sir, affront our Power.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: A power to command love; was there ever such A Solecism in Nature; besides, you mistake The Prerogative you have decreed to your selves; I must be bold to tell you so; and more, that were You Coy, and proud as Pallas, your Own law Must humble you.—

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: How so! presumptions Sir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Alas, Madam, Cupid has conspir'd with your Councels More happily for us, than the most ambitious Lover Could have hop'd for,—you will have the privilege To make love first?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: What Then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why much good do you with it—and begin; but remember As it does invert our Common Mode of Courtship in the First tender of our respects, so we may expect, (and Reasonably too) the same observances from you women, The privilege of Lady Mistresses being no longer yours: In short, you have pull'd down your Altars of love And have set up ours.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Was there ever such an affront to Cupid, and women In power together?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
I must be plainer yet: and assure you that you have
Put it justly in our power to expect, not only that you Should first offer your affections; but with the exemplary humilities of men, when lying at the feet of Their Mistresses, as by saying, I am, Sir, your humble Lady To serve you—how happy were I to have the least Of your good opinion! What a foot, and hand have you, And eye that sends forth rays more bright than those of Diamonds, and wounds with every beam a Lover; and So till you come (for want of hair) to our Perriwigs, And admire them as much.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: This were fine indeed.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Nay, after you have perform'd all this, remain In doubt whether we'll receive it, or no, but give You as endless and insupportable delays as such Of your Sex usually do, when proud, fair, rich, and Witty, are compleated in one individual woman—If this be not Justice, according to your determination Of making love; I submit to your judgments, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: God a mercy Sophister! thou hast puzzl'd their reasons I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I was beholding to thy wit for the hint, Meridith:

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: I am glad it did you service.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: And with such a retortion on themselves?

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: What say you to this Ladies?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I doubt the argument is unavoidable.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: And contradict our decree.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: I confess the consequence was overseen by us.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: Why let us revoke it then, and make a better in its Stead.

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p: 'Tis necessary, since we are like to have no lovers Otherwise.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Rather than so, I'd consent to give up our Government.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: We must think of some other expedient. In the mean Time, I'll vouchsafe you my pardon.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And your love too, I hope, Madam, by that Eye
She gave me first—
And last, I dare conclude it.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: His wit has taken me.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: And so for you Sir, I suppose we may do the like.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: I thank you, Lady:—but you shall chuse some Other Gallant in stead of me for your service.—

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And what for me?

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: Good picture of time, nothing.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: You have been admitted a Platonick already, By our particular dispensation.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Me a Platonick, Lady? 't had been better said to AEson, after he renew'd his years, and youth—Me a Plaionick? I'll sooner renounce Plato, and all His spiritual Doctrine of Love, ten times over, Than suffer the affront to flesh and blood of mine. Me a Platonick?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Well Sir, I will allow your years a greater respect Since you desire it.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And can deserve it too! but do not hope for a return Unless you value me at the price of one and Twenty in man-hood, I'll not go under a day, fair One, and on those terms, love, embrace, and welcome; which If thou dost with me, I'll make thee know, thou art To wish thy self yonger for my sake, and not me for Thine.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I conceive you, Sir—such a humour in age, what's more Taking?—

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Eugenia, thou hast clos'd this Scene more kindly than I look'd for—Come Ladies—

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Well, Frankman, thou hast shew'd thy self a true Witt indeed.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I told you, I should bow the proudest she amongst them.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: And has given some shock to their dominion over us.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why I design'd it man; and if we do not set up What we please now, 'tis our own faults; I knew From the beginning of this day, that the Power would Be our Sexes again, with more pleasure than before.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Serina made the first breach.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Were she rewarded though with a greater dignity Than I'll name, I could afford it her.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: She affects Polidor, no less deserving in his birth And vertues.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Away to thy Father, Featlin, Thy design ripens a pace.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: I was just going to him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: I did not think that providence had bless'd Sir Grave Solymour with so hopeful a Son.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Here comes Peacock, and half naked too.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: An odd spectacle of mirth.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I'll dispose of him accordingly—In the mean time Wait you on Polidor—
How now, Peacock?

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: The most sad man living, Sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: The matter Sir? why I have lost my self, Sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And thou here?

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: I mean Euphorbus, my other lovely being in my self.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But how com'st thou to be half uncloath'd too?

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: Why Sir, as I was this afternoon asleep, having Laid my fine Vest of Feathers by me, I had it stoln Away from me, my Pocket pick'd too, and, as I suppose, By that self of mine, Euphorbus.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: A good moral of self love; than which nothing More deceives us—but to undecieve thee, I'll tell Thee Jack, that self of thine was but a Link-Boy Design'd to abuse thy Credulity, and for the Artist You dealt with, he's obscur'd already, besides not Worth a revenge.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: Is't possible, Sir? then I have been abominably cheated By that pretended Virtuoso you directed me to.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I did consent for thy good, he should practise on thee A little, since 'twas a just punishment of thy humour Of self affection, and may all that doat too much Upon themselves deceive themselves accordingly.

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: I care not for my mony, If I had but my suit of Feathers again!

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No matter whether thou hast for no, or thou mayst have As good.—

sp.speaker: Peac.
sp.p: Do you think so! I'll try all the feather Shops in the Town, before I'll rest then.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: In the mean time thy part of Comedy shall end here: Be gone Jack—as thou art a lover of Modes and dress I would no thave thee seen in such a plight as this.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: And have you power or other means to accomplish this Design, Serina?

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: I doubt it not, and know most noble Polidor, that as this Day began with womens rule, so it shall end propitious To my Countreys happiness and my acknowledgments of your Desert.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: I need no other proof than your vertue—here's Frankman.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: And must be acquainted how I proceed; Mr. Frankman?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Your Will, Madam.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: How came you off with the Ladies?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: With victory enough, Madam, in so much that I judge They could be contented to rule jointly with us now.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: And by what means?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: By a small heat of argument, on the account of Love Madam, the most subduing passion.—

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: My design is half perfected, by this ingenuity of his—And what for Crispina.—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why, as proud, and stout as she is, she plies, and shall More yet, as I hope to order matters.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: You will deserve her best affection.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: And for my friend Meridith here—the wonder of age And love, he has made such a fair Progress with Eugenia Too.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: A vertuous and discreet Lady.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: I was fain, Madam, to come up close to her, and bid her Expect what her youth could hope, from mine—till we Came to such a kind reperteè by looks, that I suppose She could even have sung, I like his humour well, and I like his humour well.—

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: A pleasant one I assure you.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: And shall be, till life and I take leave Madam.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: Besides he is a person no less generous, in all his actions I must owne him such.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: You shall be sure to prove me so, when you command My service.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: There needs nothing, but to insist on your prerogatives as men.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Which we'l be certain in the end to have the Better of Women kind, or I know nothing of Flesh and blood.—

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: And be sure, you neither receive their address or make love On any terms, giving the like intimation to all you think Fit—the other part of the design shall be mine and Celinda's.—

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: I am prepar'd to serve it—but With your leave first.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: I know your affair, come Polidor, and you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: And do you hope to bed with me at night, You AEthiopian Matron, do you?

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: I shall expect, Sir, the due respects, and observance of a Wife.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Indeed sooty, Madam.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: The very reason, Sir, that Chimney-sweepers are more Regarded in our Countrey than in any other, because They come so near the complexion of our Ladies.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Or else for my greater Curse, thou wert begotten by one at Home and so foisted on me.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: By your leave Sir, I must taste your lips
'Tis my privilege to begin, our Law says.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Would I could tell where to hire some Villain to Strangle her.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: I have made my self known to him.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: That's well: but be sure to keep back the Plot, till our design be perfected:

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Leave it to me.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: Serina expects me—I'll but salute him now.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: Besides, Sir, we Moors are held in pleasure to transcend The most beautiful embraces, the world (as well as Those under our Meridian) affirms it.

lg.l: Whilst we such amorous Feats can do,
The fair would wish to act and know,
Which makes it hard with us to prove
Whether Honour greater is than love.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p:
She abuses me in Rhime too! though it be the
Curse of Poetry.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: Your servant Sir.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: She here to second her?

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: To serve you, I am.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: My fair Trapanner I desire no more of your service—

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: And provided you will but hope well from me—Perhaps may yet oblige your good opinion—

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Is that possible, after decoying me to this mischief?

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Good Father be more comfortably perswaded, and if you are Not pleas'd to expect well from her, trust to my Endeavour.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: If thou canst relieve me in this affliction, this Cross Of mine will prove a welcome providence in obliging My love for ever to thee.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: I do not doubt it Sir.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Tho' I confess it a just punishment of my vitious inclinations And hypocrisy, together with my too long injurious Neglect of thee.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: You have no design to do me wrong I hope—

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: As you are a woman, not I, Lady.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: She is rather an African Serpent in the Sun-burn'd form Of woman, there is danger in changing words with her.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: But if I provide a Spell, Sir, shall charm your Quiet and freedome?

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: Do you assure it?

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: As I am honest, and obedient, I do, so you express Your self a Father.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: My love, and Estate shall confirm thee, Take all, or what Part thou wilt, of which I must acknowledge my covetousness has too many years injuriously debarr'd thee.
sp.stage: Enter Serina, Crispina, Eugenia, Petilla, and the two Ladies.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Here comes the women, Sir,—please you to confirm it Within.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: With my hand seal & heart—

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p:
I could have wish'd Ladies, that the men had been more Moderate in their resolution—But here it
is at large.
sp.stage: [They open a Scrowl of Parchment and look on.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: And confirm'd by all these hands.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Not a considerable person in the Common-wealth almost, But has set his name here.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: And that malapert toy, my Husband too?

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: I do not find his name here—but it may be those You like as well.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Not receive, or make love, except we part with our power! A bold demand, Ladies.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: And before we have govern'd one day.

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p: It seems they conclude we shall be necessitated to yield Before night.—

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: You see how firmly they have resolv'd, and under the Honour of their hands too, not to love in any kind, on Other terms.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: Part with our power? why, 'tis that which Princes fight for, Polititians deceive for, nay, Mistresses love for.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: I and women marry for; I did, I am sure, chiefly On the account of governing.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: 'Tis doubtless some trick of these men to obtain the Supremacy we possess.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: I judge so, Madam.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: They are men, I doubt not, and let 'em live in our country And not love if they can—for my part I should rather Be content to starve my affection a while, than not Maintain our rule—tho' perhaps I have something Might concern me, as much as another woman.—

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: A magnanimous resolution!

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: But I fear the consequence.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: O, Ladies, if ever for loves sake you will conclude On any thing, you must do it this minute.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: You must live, and love alone else, the men are all leaving Of our Country, and you'l not have a man of sixteen in Utopia, By Sun set.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Is it certain?

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: Why then let us be content till the Boys come to be men.

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p: I doubt that will be too long for some of our constitutions.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Right, Madam, and might prejudice us more than our Power is worth, there is no living without 'em.

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p: A Barbarism not to be admitted by our Sex.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: I have heard of a Chymist, that undertakes to make men, If true, now were a time to imploy him.

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p: But the cheat's discover'd and hee's run away.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: Nay, Ladies, you must presently determine, the Shipps are taken, the Wind fair, and whereas I Said a man, we shall not have otherwise a Boy To play with.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Not a boy to play with, neither?—have we not Power to restrain these bold Insolents from making This attempt.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: If we could I conceive it were to little purpose, unless we Can command their loves.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Mr. Frankman going too! well! I have a womans heart, I Find.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And Meridith too! methinks I am unwilling our Countrey Should want such an ornament of age.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: Let us put our selves wholly in Serina's hands, and comply As she shall think fit.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Content, content.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: And will you all submit to what I shall conclude, or Determine?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: As we are women we will.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: That may prove a fickle assurance.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: As we hope to love, and be belov'd again, Madam.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: That's somewhat surer—And since you are thus unanimous Know 'tis for some reasons my design and not The mens,—see here, they come, will answer For the rest, and acceptably I hope.
sp.stage: Whispers Celinda, who brings in Polidor, Frankman, Meridith.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: We need not doubt it.—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I suppose we may make love first now—but Keep back yours, Sir, a while, I have some Reasons.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: You shall advise me.—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p:
And now, Meridith, what think'st thou on that
Sprightly cast, Eugenia darted on thee?

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: Why, did I not give her beam for beam, think'st Thou?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Well said—and for you Crispina, as you are stout and Proud—

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: What then Sir?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why, I'll grant thee so much victory, as to bid me Take thee, 'tis something like the decree you made, But it shall be only with the spiritual language Of thy eye—Nay that's too much of Madam Haughty.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: 'Tis a hard case, Sir, if I have no look to please you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Now, she comes, i'faith, methinks I am even abed
Withthee in that cast—and in this something
More—give me thy hand, and as I am a Frankman I'll love thee, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Crisp.
sp.p: I am yours then it seems.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I hope to both our happinesses—there is no such Wife As a proud woman makes when humbl'd, like the Stately'st Horse that seems most comely under the Rider.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: Eugenia, your affections are fix'd here.—If I mistake not.—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I must acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: But I'll save her the labour, Madam, to bid me take her: I know thou lov'st me, and lik'st my humour well too, and If I do not enjoy thee as chearfully—may I be never More call'd the youthful Meridith.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I shall as much rejoyce your love, and though at such a disstance 'Twixt our years, we are united, (so seldom an example in my Sex) I'll bear the Censure, since pleasant humour's More to be esteem'd, and cements faster love Than youth and beauty.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: For which I'll be thy mirthful companion, friend And Husband, and will live with thee merrily up, and More merrily down.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: I cannot blame her to be taken, and his disposition so Pleasant.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p:
Notwithstanding I am a Wife, I might have expected Something like an Amour too—but there is time
For all things.

sp.speaker: 2. Lad.
sp.p: Doubt it not, Lady.

sp.speaker: 1. Lad.
sp.p: I should be sorry, if I could not dispose of my virginity With content too, when I please.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Here comes Sir Grave Solymour.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: More conventions of women to Encrease my vexation.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: You need not apprehend it father—this is but your last Scene, and I'll make it a short one.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: I have perform'd all things you requir'd of me.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: And I'll free you from this black Wife in spight Of the decree is past.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.p: You will not do me such an injustice Sir.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: No, he shall not, but I will—the Plot is mine And I'll discover it my self, to deserve his favour With you; look you here, Sir, 'tis but a Blackamoor Boy, and my Page—I hope Ladies there
sp.stage: Pulls off the Moors hood, and he appears a Blackamoor.
sp.p: Needs no decree to annul this marriage.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: Celinda has oblig'd you Knight.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: I thank her, Madam, since she has done me No greater Mischief

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: And reconcil'd you to your Son, likewise.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Most fully, Sir, I thank him, and with a settlement of His Estate on me.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: I knew this only could effect it on your covetousness, and do your Son justice, whom you had Long injur'd—wherefore you ought Sir to pardon The design,

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: I do, I do,—since there's no remedy.—

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: For which your so worthy affection—I offer my Self and fortune yours.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: It is but justice.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: I was yours without it, and am so now.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: There's no more for me to do.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir!—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But to reform your self and that square pretext Of Gravity, by which you have not a little abus'd Better meanings than your own.

sp.speaker: Soly.
sp.p: I will than immediately retire, and live, (if I can) A forgotten Common-wealths man.—

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: A happy riddance, believe me.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: You have oblig'd me, Mr. Frankman, with the rest.

sp.speaker: Celin.
sp.p: You should have thank'd the Ladies too, but that I'll do for you.—
sp.stage: [She courtsies to Serina and the women.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: There's yet a higher justice to be done unto you Polidor—nor is't unknown that in your veins Is still preserv'd, that Royal Blood, which first gave Nourishment unto this Countrey's antient stock Of Kings.

sp.speaker: Omn. Cit.
sp.p: We all acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: And from my mouth I dare pronounce you here Our Monarch—I know you will accept it.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: I were injurious otherwise unto your love And Justice, tho' time by introducing long these Forms of State, obscur'd the light and glory Of my first Ancestors.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: But to be more conspicuous in your self.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: You shall partake it with me, Serina, and more, I Will acknowledge that 'tis thy love and vertue made Me King.

sp.speaker: Serin.
sp.p: You have already Sir, above my expectation or desert.

sp.speaker: Omn. Cit.
sp.p: Long live Polidor and Serina, King and Queen.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: And to you all I'll soon express the value that I have for your affections.

sp.speaker: Frank. Featl.
sp.p: We do not doubt it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: For me, I'll only beg, that when our Countrey's Enemies Shall dare provoke your Arms, you'l bid me be your Souldier.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: With Eugenia's leave thou shalt, nay call'd in honour. Of thy Youthful Age, my youngest Captain.

sp.speaker: Merid.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: You are contented Ladies with this change.

sp.speaker: Omn. Lad.
sp.p: With all submission, Sir.

sp.speaker: Featl.
sp.p: And is an universal joy in this most happy end Of both Republicks.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: But I hope, Sir, Wives shall not lose their legislative Power in ruling of their Husbands.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: For such as will submit, wee'l make no law to Hinder them.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.p: Then you are a King indeed.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: Nature has made for men her Salique-Law Given Women to continue men, not govern, And though both Sexes here have held Republicks (A usage diff'rent from all other Countreys) In each example they may wisely see No rule's so good as lawful Monarchy.

div.head: Epilogue spoke by Mr. Foppering.
div.l: THe Stages Zany, or the Miss that's kind
Poets their Intercessors Wisely find:
The fool's your favourite, and the Miss can play
A far more welcome part anotherway;
But stay, this Jest must not proceed too far,
Our women govern here—as well as there,
Beauty is sacred, and a Satyr thence
Is like a Clap in Cupids kinder sence.
Then let them pass with their Heroick guilt,
And Prologue borrow'd from a Hat and Belt.
Farce may be us'd in the Romantick way,
Like Pudding Jack turn'd Hector in a Play.
Wee'l act such fools our Poets can suppose,
Rather than Hero's imitating those,
Yet mine I hope so far with theirs complies,
That Foppering you'l excuse for telling lyes.
A Fools bold Lunacy my part does show,
But more Heroick Cinthia's Hero know.
Great AEsop did by Fools the Wise direct,
Allow our Author's hear the same effect,
He for your sake his Comick-Muse thus dress'd,
But hopes the Moral is above the Jest:
And if y' are kind upon our Poets score,
We Actors, in that fauour, hope for more.
